    </div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">18</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
    <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
    </div><br>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Objectives of Our Executive Compensation
Program </font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The structure of our executive
compensation program is designed to compensate and reward executives
appropriately for driving superior performance. For our Named Executive
Officers, a significant portion of their total direct compensation is "at risk"
and tied closely to the success of the Corporation&#8217;s short and long-term
objectives. "At risk" means that the executive will not realize value unless
specified goals, many of which are directly tied to the Corporation&#8217;s
performance, are achieved or the price at which our common shares are traded on
the TSX or NASDAQ appreciates. In 2009, these performance goals, and resulting
compensation awards, were largely focused on the Corporation&#8217;s key business
drivers including growing revenue, increasing product shipments, reducing
product costs, development of the FCgen&#8482;-1300 product and reducing annual
operating cash consumption. This compensation philosophy puts a strong emphasis
on pay for performance, and uses equity awards as a significant component in
order to correlate the long-term growth of shareholder value with management&#8217;s
most significant compensation opportunities. The strategic goals of the
Corporation are reflected in the incentive-based executive compensation programs
so that executives&#8217; interests are aligned with shareholders interests.
</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Philosophy and Objectives
</font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Our philosophy and objectives regarding
compensation are to: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LINE-HEIGHT: 12pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; ">
<tr>
            <td nowrap valign="top">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
    </td>
            <td nowrap valign="top"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(a)</font></td>
            <td nowrap>&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </td>
            <td width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">attract and
      retain experienced, qualified, capable executive officers by paying
      salaries which are competitive in the markets in which we compete for
      executive talent;</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td nowrap>
            </td>
            <td colspan="3" width="100%">&#160;</td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td nowrap valign="top">
            </td>
            <td nowrap valign="top"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(b)</font></td>
            <td nowrap>
            </td>
            <td width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">motivate
      short and long-term performance by directly linking annual bonuses to
      performance; and</font> </td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td nowrap>
            </td>
            <td colspan="3" width="100%">&#160;</td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td nowrap valign="top">
            </td>
            <td nowrap valign="top"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(c)</font></td>
            <td nowrap>
            </td>
            <td width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">link our
      executive officers' interests with those of our shareholders by providing
      our executive officers with equity-based compensation, requiring them to
      comply with minimum share ownership guidelines and build a sustained
      ownership position.</font></td>
          </tr></table>
    </div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">How Executive Compensation is Determined
</font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The MDNCC is charged, on behalf of our
Board, with reviewing and approving executive officers&#8217; benefit policies and
compensation plans, including our annual bonus plan and our long-term
equity-based compensation plans. As part of its mandate, the committee approves
and recommends to the Board the appointment of our executive officers. The
committee also reviews and approves the amount and form of their compensation,
their development and succession plans, and any significant organizational or
management changes. The committee retains independent compensation consultants
for professional advice and as a source of competitive market information. In
2009, the committee directly retained Towers Perrin to provide independent
compensation analysis and advice specifically related to Ballard executive
compensation items. The committee also seeks the advice and recommendations of
our President and Chief Executive Officer with respect to the compensation of
our other executive officers. The President and Chief Executive Officer does not
participate in the portions of the committee discussions that relate directly to
his personal compensation. </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Executive Pay Mix and the Emphasis on "At
Risk" Pay </font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">We place emphasis on performance by
having a significant proportion of our executive officers&#8217; total annual
compensation linked to corporate and individual performance. For 2009, an
average of 55% of the annual compensation earned by each of our Named Executive
Officers<font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(1)</font>
</font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">came from "at risk",
variable, performance-related compensation containing inherent market
performance risk, where annual compensation includes base salary, annual bonus
and equity-based long-term incentives (including share options and
RSUs).<br><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">____________________</font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="FONT-SIZE: 8pt; LINE-HEIGHT: 10pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; ">
<tr>
            <td nowrap valign="top"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(1)</font></td>
            <td nowrap>&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </td>
            <td width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Mr. Smith
      was not included as a Named Executive Officer for the purposes of
      calculating &#8220;at risk&#8221; compensation, as he resigned as Vice President and
      Chief Financial Officer on January 30, 2009 and did not receive any
      variable, performance-related
compensation.</font></td>
          </tr></table>
    </div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">19</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
    <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
    </div><br>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Use of Benchmarking
</font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Our overall compensation objective is to
pay executives on average at the 50<font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">th</font> </font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">percentile of the comparator group for
full achievement of performance goals. Over-achievement or under-achievement
will result in being over or under the average.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">In 2008, the MDNCC, working with Towers
Perrin, updated the comparator companies contained within the Corporation&#8217;s
compensation comparator group to better reflect the Corporation&#8217;s business size
and market focus following the divestment of the automotive business in January
2008. A new list of comparator companies was reviewed and accepted by the
committee, which selected the group of comparators ensuring a suitable mix of
Canadian and United States companies exhibiting a growth oriented mix of
revenues, employee base, asset base, market capitalization and market focus.
This comparator group comprised the primary source of compensation data for
review of the Corporation&#8217;s market competitiveness. The committee reviews the
composition of the comparator company list on an annual basis.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The committee compares each executive
officer&#8217;s annual salary, target annual incentive bonus and long-term incentive
compensation value, both separately and in the aggregate, to amounts paid for
similar positions at comparator group companies. As noted above, the committee&#8217;s
practice is to target annual total direct compensation for each executive at
approximately the 50<font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">th</font> </font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">percentile among the comparator group
companies. </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</font>The Corporation&#8217;s current comparator
group is:</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="PADDING-LEFT: 5pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LINE-HEIGHT: 14pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; ">
<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" width="47%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Canadian Companies</font><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(2)</font></font></td>
            <td align="left" width="5%">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</td>
            <td align="left" width="48%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">United States
      Companies</font></font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" width="47%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Gennum Corporation</font></td>

  Inc.</font></td>

            <td align="left" width="47%">

            <td align="left" width="5%">

            <td align="left" width="48%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">PMC-Sierra Inc.</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" width="47%">
            </td>
            <td align="left" width="5%">
            </td>
            <td align="left" width="48%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Plug Power Inc.</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" width="47%">
            </td>
            <td align="left" width="5%">
            </td>
            <td align="left" width="48%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Power Integrations Inc.</font></td>
          </tr></table>
    </div><br>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Current Executive Compensation Elements
</font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</font>Our compensation program for our
executive officers has three primary components: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LINE-HEIGHT: 12pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; ">
<tr>
            <td nowrap valign="top">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
    </td>
            <td nowrap valign="top"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(a)</font></td>
            <td nowrap>&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </td>
            <td width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">annual
      salary;</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td nowrap>
            </td>
            <td colspan="3" width="100%">&#160;</td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td nowrap valign="top">
            </td>
            <td nowrap valign="top"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(b)</font></td>
            <td nowrap>
            </td>
            <td width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">annual
      incentives (bonus); and</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td nowrap>
            </td>
            <td colspan="3" width="100%">&#160;</td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td nowrap valign="top">
            </td>
            <td nowrap valign="top"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(c)</font></td>
            <td nowrap>
            </td>
            <td width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">equity-based
      long-term incentives comprised of awards that may be issued under our
      Option Plan or under the Market Purchase RSU
Plan.</font></td>
          </tr></table>
    </div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Annual Salary </font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The MDNCC approves the annual salary of
our executive officers. Salary guidelines and salary adjustments for our
executive officers are considered with reference to: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LINE-HEIGHT: 12pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; ">
<tr>
            <td nowrap valign="top">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
    </td>
            <td nowrap valign="top"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(a)</font></td>
            <td nowrap>&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </td>
            <td width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">comparative
      market assessments performed by external compensation
    consultants;</font></td>
          </tr></table>
    </div>____________________<br>&#160;<br>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="FONT-SIZE: 8pt; LINE-HEIGHT: 10pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; ">
<tr>
            <td nowrap valign="top"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(2)</font></td>
            <td>&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </td>
            <td width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Xantrex
      Technology was removed from the Canadian comparator group in 2009
      following its acquisition by Schneider
Electric.</font></td>
          </tr></table>
    </div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">20</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
    <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
    </div>
    <div style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><br>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; (b) the experience
and qualifications of each executive
officer;<br><br>&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; (c) the
individual performance of each executive officer;
and<br><br>&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; (d) the roles
and responsibilities of each executive officer. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation chooses to pay this
element of compensation, because the Corporation&#8217;s view is that a competitive
base salary is a necessary element for attracting and retaining qualified and
experienced executive talent. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation&#8217;s decisions about this
element of compensation and its annual level impacts decisions about the level
of target annual incentive an executive might receive, but only in the sense
that the incentive bonus target is set as a percentage of annual salary.
</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">In 2009, there were no annual salary
increases for the Named Executive Officers. As an austerity measure, in August
2009, the full-time Named Executive Officers voluntarily accepted a temporary
10% reduction in base salary, consistent with the Corporation's overall cost
reduction efforts.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Annual Bonus for Executive Officers
</font></font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The MDNCC reviews and approves the annual
bonus for each executive officer based on the recommendations of our President
and Chief Executive Officer in accordance with the factors described in the
foregoing section. Ballard has historically paid the annual bonus in Shares or
in DSUs. Starting with 2009 performance awards, the Corporation commenced the
payment of annual bonuses for our Named Executive Officers in cash. This change
is consistent with the overall move away from the use of treasury shares for
compensation purposes and the changes approved by shareholders in 2009 related
to the consolidation and funding of the Corporation's share and option based
plans.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The annual target bonus for executive
officers (excluding the President and Chief Executive Officer) was set at 70% of
base salary in 2009. This bonus target had been reduced in 2008 to 70% from 75%
in 2007 (this reduction followed a similar reduction in the target bonus level
of 5% from 2006 levels to better align annual incentive levels to market levels
relative to the Corporation&#8217;s comparator group). Each executive officer&#8217;s actual
2009 bonus was based on a combination of his individual performance and our
corporate performance relative to goals, as discussed below under the section
entitled "Methodology for Determining Annual Incentives". </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation maintains an annual bonus
program in order to motivate short and long-term performance by directly linking
annual bonuses to the performance and progress of the Corporation. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation&#8217;s decisions about this
element of compensation do not directly affect decisions about any other element
of the Corporation&#8217;s compensation program. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">For a full discussion of annual incentive
compensation for our President and Chief Executive Officer, see the section
entitled "Chief Executive Officer Compensation". The section below entitled
"Methodology for Determining Annual Incentives" applies equally to the President
and Chief Executive Officer as it does to the other executives. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-DECORATION: underline"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Methodology for Determining Annual
Incentives</font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">
</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The actual annual bonus for each
executive officer is determined by the MDNCC on the basis of the following
formula:</font></div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">&#160;</font></div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">annual base
salary x target bonus percentage x individual performance multiplier x corporate
multiplier. </font></div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">&#160;</font></div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font size="3">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</font>The corporate multiplier is
determined by the MDNCC and approved by the Board with reference to achievement
against the corporate goals set out in a Corporate Performance Scorecard
approved by the MDNCC and the Board prior to the commencement of the year (in
December 2008 for the 2009 fiscal year). Each corporate performance goal on the
scorecard is assigned a relative weighting in terms of importance to annual
performance and growth of the Corporation, as well as a range of targeted
outcomes, such that below a certain performance level the contribution of that
goal to the overall corporate multiplier is zero. One of the goals set at the
start of the year related to Unit Shipments of FCgen&#8482;-1030 cogeneration stacks
to Ebara Ballard Corporation in Japan. Following the Corporation's strategic
decision in mid-year to exit the Ebara Ballard Corporation joint venture, the
Board decided to refine the performance criteria replacing the unit shipment
goal with a qualitative assessment of corporate performance based on preparing
for and implementing the Corporation's subsequent strategic decision to exit the
Ebara Ballard Corporation joint venture.&#160;</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">21</font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
      <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
      </div><br>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">&#160;</font>&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The 2009 Corporate Performance Scorecard
had 15 key elements. Goals related to the successful implementation of the Ebara
Ballard Joint Venture exit, Fuel Cell Cost Targets associated with the
FCgen&#8482;-1020ACS product, On-Time delivery of Manufacturing Orders, the EBITDA
target for our Carbon Fibre Materials division and Working Capital Targets were
all exceeded and received between 100% to 150% scoring in the overall corporate
multiplier.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Targets related to FCgen&#8482;-1300 product
development goals and Fuel Cell Cost Targets associated with the
FCvelocity&#8482;-9SSL product were met and received between 90% to 100% scoring in
the overall corporate multiplier.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Targets related to total Revenue, overall
EBITDA, Fuel Cell Shipments to the Back-Up Power and Material Handling markets,
Revenue and EBTIDA targets for the bus market segment, EBITDA target for the
supporting Automotive business segment, and Operation Cash Consumption were not
met and received 0% scoring in the overall corporate multiplier. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The overall corporate multiplier for
2009, as reviewed and agreed to by the MDNCC and the Board, based on achievement
relative to these corporate goals, was 53%.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Given the nature of the corporate
performance multiplier, for any particular year the corporate performance
multiplier is not determined until our annual financial statements for that
particular financial year are complete. However, notwithstanding that the
corporate performance multiplier is not determined, and the annual bonus based
thereon is not paid until the first quarter following each particular financial
year, in our summary compensation table we report the annual bonus for each
particular financial year as if it had been determined and paid in the
particular financial year.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">A discussion of the annual base salary,
target bonus percentage and corporate multiplier components of this annual
incentive formula for each executive officer is set out above. The individual
performance multiplier is determined with reference to achievement against the
individual goals set for each executive officer, with an individual performance
multiplier greater than 100% being awarded for superior performance against
these goals, and an individual performance multiplier of less than 100% being
awarded for substandard performance against these goals. Individual goals are
set for individual executive officers by the Chief Executive Officer and are
based on agreed-upon objective/identifiable measures relative to their
respective functional accountabilities, which are aligned to the corporate
performance goals. Our Named Executive Officers&#8217; individual performance
multipliers for 2009 ranged from 80% to 130%.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Mr. Cousins was appointed Chief Financial
Officer on April 6, 2009. Mr. Cousins has met his overall performance goals for
his CFO role, related to financial operations, administration, investor
relations and information technology since the date of his appointment. In
addition he provided strong leadership on key initiatives including the
re-setting of the cost base and two key transactions to augment the Company&#8217;s
cash reserves (the Ford Share Purchase Agreement monetization and the head
office building sale-leaseback).</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Mr. Nanji&#8217;s role changed from the Chief
Customer Officer role that he held in 2008, with responsibilities for Sales,
Marketing and Business Development responsibilities, to a part-time, one year
transitional role that completed on December 31, 2009. This transitional role
was part of Mr. Nanji&#8217;s plan to leave Ballard after over 10 years of service, to
pursue new career opportunities. In his transitional role, he assisted the CEO
and the new Chief Commercial Officer on a number of projects, with a primary
focus on strategic matters, including the exit from the Ebara Ballard joint
venture business in Japan. He left the Company as planned on December 31,
2009.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Mr. Guzy&#8217;s primary responsibilities for
2009, in his role of Vice President and Chief Technology Officer, were in
research programs, product development and project implementation. Research
programs met all key goals, including securing a significant increase in
external funding from government sources. While the major development programs,
including FCgen&#8482;-1300 product development and the BC Transit and First Energy
implementation activities were effectively executed, several milestones were
missed, largely related to external factors.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">22</font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
      <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
      </div><br>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Mr. Goldstein was appointed Vice
President and Chief Commercial Officer on April 27, 2009. Mr. Goldstein
initiated key programs in 2009 to build strong organizational capabilities,
enhanced sales training and funnel management processes and heightened the
business focus on distributed generation business opportunities. Other than
revenue results, which fell short of the goals due to the external environment,
key goals were delivered in 2009. In addition, Mr. Goldstein played a key role
in the architecture and negotiation of the Dantherm Power acquisition.
</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Mr. Smith resigned as Vice President and
Chief Financial Officer on January 30, 2009 and did not receive an annual bonus
for 2009.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Long Term Incentives </font></font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">We provide our executive officers with
equity-based long-term incentives through the Option Plan, Market Purchase RSU
Plan and the SDP. These plans are designed to reinforce the connection between
executive officer remuneration and our performance by motivating and rewarding
participants for improving our long-term financial strength and enhancing
shareholder value, and also providing retention value to executives. With
respect to equity-based long-term compensation awards for our executive
officers, individual performance and future contribution expectations are taken
into account in determining the award. In 2009, the President and Chief
Executive Officer recommended to the MDNCC a value amount in dollars for each
Named Executive Officer which considered the previous comparator company study
by Towers Perrin, and the current share price and total options and shares
available for issuance under the Option Plan and SDP, which was approved for
each executive: see the amounts set out under &#8220;Share-Based Awards&#8221; and
&#8220;Option-Based Awards&#8221; in our Summary Compensation Table. Approximately 55% of
this value amount was then converted to RSUs at the then current market price by
dividing the dollar value by the closing share price on either the TSX or NASDAQ
on the award date. Approximately 45% of this value amount was converted to
options by dividing the dollar value by the Black-Scholes value of a Ballard
option on the award date. These options were then priced at the closing share
price on the day prior to the award date. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">A new hire Long Term Incentive award
consisting of both options and RSUs was given to each Mr. Cousins and Mr.
Goldstein upon their appointment as executives to the Corporation in April
2009.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">This element of compensation and the
Corporation&#8217;s decisions about this element fit into the Corporation&#8217;s overall
compensation objectives in that they link our shareholders&#8217; interests with those
of our executive officers by providing our executive officers with equity-based
compensation, and requiring them to comply with minimum share ownership
guidelines. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation&#8217;s decisions about this
element of compensation do not affect decisions about any other element of the
Corporation&#8217;s compensation. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-DECORATION: underline"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Share Options</font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Share options are granted annually in
respect of approximately 50% of the long-term compensation to be provided to an
executive. As a result, previous grants of Share options are not generally taken
into account when making new grants. The actual number of Share options granted
is determined by dividing the dollar value of the portion of the long-term
incentive to be satisfied though an option grant by the Black-Scholes value of a
Ballard option on the award date. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</font>Under our Option Plan: </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
        <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LINE-HEIGHT: normal; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; ">
<tr style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify;">
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
    </td>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(a)</font></td>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </td>
              <td valign="top" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">the exercise price of each option
      is determined by the Board, but must not be less than the closing price
      per Share on the TSX on the last trading day before the date the option is
      granted; and</font></td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td nowrap style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td colspan="3" valign="top" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;</td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(b)</font></td>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td valign="top" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">each option may be exercised by the
      holder in respect of up to one-third of the Shares subject to the option
      on or after the first, second and third anniversary of the effective date
      of the option on a cumulative basis.</font></td>
            </tr></table>
      </div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">&#160;</font></div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</font>Share options are typically granted
for a term of seven years. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">23</font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
      <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
      </div><br>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">As an austerity measure, reflecting the
economic climate and lower share price levels, the target dollar value of 2009
Share Options was reduced by approximately 30% from 2008 levels. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-DECORATION: underline"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Restricted Share Units</font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Employees and executive officers are
eligible to receive new RSU awards under the Market Purchase RSU Plan, which
provides for vesting over periods of up to three years and awards may be subject
to certain performance criteria, as determined by the Board upon the
recommendation of the MDNCC. Redemption of these RSUs is satisfied with Shares
bought under the Market Purchase RSU Plan.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The amount of the long-term incentive
that is awarded to each executive officer is typically determined in the first
quarter of each financial year, in conjunction with the determination of that
executive officer&#8217;s annual bonus for the prior financial year. Since the
long-term incentive is tied to future (as opposed to past) corporate
performance, in our summary compensation table we report the grant of the
long-term incentive in the &#8220;Share-Based Awards&#8221; column and the &#8220;Option-Based
Awards&#8221; column for the particular year in which they were actually granted. The
year-end values of unexercised or unvested Share options and RSUs, and the
vesting during the year of Share options and RSUs are reported in the tables
under the heading &#8220;Incentive Plan Awards&#8221;. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-STYLE: italic"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">New Issuances </font></font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">As an austerity measure, reflecting the
economic climate and lower share price levels, the target dollar value of 2009
RSU awards was reduced by approximately 30% from 2008 levels. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">On March 23, 2009, 203,500 RSUs were
issued to all then full-time Named Executive Officers, including the President
and Chief Executive Officer. For all our executive officers who received an
award on that date, the RSU awards included a performance criteria achievement
goal of a minimum corporate multiplier in 2009 of 75% (see the section above
entitled "Methodology for Determining Annual Incentives" for a description of
the determination of the 2009 corporate multiplier).</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">During 2009, to better align executive
compensation with long-term performance and shareholder interests, the MDNCC and
Board decided to move from awarding RSU grants with first-year performance
criteria to RSU grants with multi-year performance criteria. RSU performance
criteria now apply across all 3 years of the award, with partial vesting of
awards in each year subject to meeting the required performance criteria. This
new methodology was applied to these 2009 awards and the Corporation intends to
apply this methodology to future awards. As the 2009 performance criteria
(minimum corporate multiplier in 2009 of 75%) was not achieved, the first third
of these awards expired and will not be redeemed. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Mr. Cousins and Mr. Goldstein each
received a grant of RSUs as part of their new hire award. These RSU awards were
subject to time vesting only over 3 years. Mr. Cousins received 57,142 RSUs on
April 30, 2009 and Mr. Goldstein received 59,829 RSUs on May 5, 2009.
</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-STYLE: italic"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Redemptions</font></font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">On March 4, 2009, 35,730 RSUs reached the
end of their restriction period and after statutory withholdings, 20,116 RSUs
were redeemed into Shares, representing one-third of the 2008 annual RSU
long-term incentive award granted to Mr. Sheridan on May 12, 2008 and to Mr.
Guzy, and Mr. Nanji on February 21, 2008. These RSUs were redeemed into Shares
following the Board&#8217;s confirmation that the performance criteria (&gt;75%
achievement of the corporate multiplier in 2008) was met. The remaining
two-thirds of the RSU award will be issued to each executive officer in 2010 and
2011, provided they remain employed by the Corporation on the respective
redemption dates. Also on March 4, 2009, 24, 286 RSUs reached the end of their
restriction period and after statutory withholdings, 13,673 RSUs were redeemed
into Shares, representing one-third of the 2007 annual RSU long-term incentive
award to Mr. Sheridan, Mr. Guzy and Mr. Nanji, the performance criteria already
having been met. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">On March 9, 2009, 183,553 RSUs reached
the end of their restriction period and after statutory withholdings,103,340
RSUs were redeemed into Shares to Mr. Sheridan, Mr. Guzy and Mr. Nanji upon
completion of the time period and satisfactory completion of the performance
criteria related to RSUs awarded to these executives in March 2006. The awards
were three-year cliff vesting awards that required satisfaction of Operating
Cash Consumption targets in each of 2006, 2007 and 2008. The MDNCC and the Board
evaluated achievement against the established target and authorized the
redemption of the RSUs into Shares. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">24</font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
      <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
      </div><br>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">As approved by the Board, as part of his
transition plan, Mr. Nanji had the remaining 20,235 RSUs issued to him in 2007
and 2008 redeemed into 11,392 Shares (net of statutory withholdings) on August
27, 2009, the performance criteria already having been met. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Chief Executive Officer Compensation
</font></font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Mr. Sheridan was appointed President and
CEO by the Board on February 22, 2006. When appointed, his base salary at that
time was fixed at US$506,402</font><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(3)</font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> per year. The CEO base salary has been
frozen since that time, other than a 10% voluntary temporary reduction in
August, 2009. This base salary reduction from August until year end 2009, was
volunteered as an austerity measure in support of cost reduction initiatives
that were being implemented across the Company.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Mr. Sheridan is entitled to receive an
RRSP contribution (US$20,065<font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(4)</font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> in 2009), but changes to the corporate
RRSP program will mean a relative reduction by 50% of this benefit in 2010 and
require a matching contribution from Mr. Sheridan). Mr. Sheridan is also
entitled to receive company paid insurance premiums (US$1,931<font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(5)</font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> in 2009). </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</font>Mr. Sheridan&#8217;s target bonus for
2009, as detailed below was equal to 90% of his annual base salary. This level
of target bonus has been reduced from 100% in 2007. Mr. Sheridan&#8217;s bonus for
2009 was determined by the MDNCC on the basis of corporate financial and
operational performance reflected in the Corporate Performance Scorecard rating,
plus performance relative to the CEO&#8217;s individual goals for 2009, as approved by
the Board. The goals and the respective performance achievement are outlined
below. </font></div>
      <ul style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt">
        <li><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Development of comprehensive strategic
  plan, with trajectory &amp; enabling key performance indicators for EBITDA
  break-even in near term &amp; strong EBITDA growth in the medium term.
  </font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">This goal was met,
  as reflected in the 2009 Strategic Plan and 2010 Annual Operating Plan,
  approved by the Board.<br>&#160;</font>
          </li>
        <li><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Resolution of Ebara Ballard joint
  venture strategic issues, with respect to investment, customer and partner
  alignment. </font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">This
  goal was met, with the smooth exit from the problematic Ebara Ballard joint
  venture, with no financial encumbrances and the retention of key business
  relationships.<br>&#160;&#160; </font>
          </li>
        <li><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Strengthen leadership through
  recruitment of Chief Commercial Officer &amp; Chief Financial Officer,
  targeted development &amp; succession planning initiatives.
  </font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">This goal was met
  with successful transitions with respect to key executive departures, new
  executive appointments and the refinement of succession plans and other
  initiatives.<br>&#160;</font>
          </li>
        <li><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Navigation of macroeconomic crises,
  through mitigation &amp; exploitation plans, for unfolding risks &amp;
  opportunities. </font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">This
  goal was exceeded, through the identification and delivery of key new
  initiatives that strengthened Ballard&#8217;s balance sheet and the Company&#8217;s growth
  capabilities. This included achievements relative to re-setting the Company&#8217;s
  cost base, monetization of the Ford Share Purchase Agreement, the
  sale-leaseback transaction, and the Dantherm Power acquisition.</font>
</li>
      </ul>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">These individual goals were purposely not
weighted in advance so that the Board could retain the flexibility to assess the
overall individual performance of Mr. Sheridan after reviewing all aspects of
performance for the full year, without the constraint of a pre-set weighting on
any particular goal. <br></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">____________________</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
        <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LINE-HEIGHT: normal; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; ">
<tr style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify;">
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(3)</font></font></td>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </td>
              <td valign="top" width="100%" style="BORDER-TOP: #ffffff 1pt solid; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Mr. Sheridan&#8217;s
      salary is payable in Canadian dollars (C$530,000) and was converted into
      United States dollars for the purpose of the disclosure above using the
      Bank of Canada noon rate of exchange on December 31, 2009. </font></td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(4)</font></font></td>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td valign="top" width="100%" style="BORDER-TOP: #ffffff 1pt solid; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">RRSP
      contribution was paid in Canadian dollars (C$21,000) and was converted
      into United States dollars for the purpose of the disclosure above using
      the Bank of Canada noon rate of exchange on December 31, 2009.</font>
  </td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(5)</font></font></td>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td valign="top" width="100%" style="BORDER-TOP: #ffffff 1pt solid; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Insurance
      premiums were paid in Canadian dollars (C$2,021) and were converted into
      United States dollars for the purpose of the disclosure above using the
      Bank of Canada noon rate of exchange on December 31, 2009.</font>
  </td>

      </div>
      <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">&#160;</font></div>
      <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">25</font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
      <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
      </div><br>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">After assessing the above achievements
relative to the goals, the Board approved an individual performance multiplier
of 140%. Applying this individual multiplier and the corporate multiplier of 53%
</font>(determined in accordance with the corporate multiplier methodology set
forth in the section entitled "Methodology for Determining Annual Incentives"),
to Mr. Sheridan&#8217;s target bonus for 2009 of 90% of base salary, resulted in a
bonus payment to Mr. Sheridan of US$338,175<font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(6)</font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> for the fiscal year ended December 31,
2009. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</font>The total value of Mr. Sheridan's
compensation in 2009 was US$1,169,163. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">On March 4, 2009, the Board approved the
recommendation by the MDNCC and Mr. Sheridan was granted a long-term incentive
award, equivalent at the time of grant to a total value of US$299,492. On March
5, 2009 a total of US$115,242 was converted to options in respect of 177,295
Shares (at an exercise price of CDN$1.34 per Share). On March 23, 2009,
following the establishment of the Market Purchase RSU Plan, Mr. Sheridan
received a RSU award of US$184,250 (137,500 RSUs at a price of CDN$1.40 per
Share). These awards formed Mr. Sheridan&#8217;s 2009 long-term incentive package, and
the overall value and equity mix was approved by the MDNCC and the Board
following consultations with Towers Perrin. Consistent with other Named
Executive Officers, the RSU award had performance criteria and time vesting as
described above in the Restricted Share Units &#8211; New Issuances section, and the
share options were granted with a 7-year term, with one-third of the options
vesting at the end of each of the first three years. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Termination and Change of Control
Benefits </font></font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">For a description of the termination and
change of control benefits under Ballard's employee contracts and equity
compensation plans for the President &amp; CEO and other Named Executive
Officers, see the section entitled "Termination and Change of Control Benefits"
below. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Perquisites </font></font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">In addition to cash and equity
compensation, the Corporation provides Named Executive Officers with certain
personal benefits, consistent with similar benefits coverage within the
comparator group. These benefits include a car allowance, medical benefits
program, long and short-term disability coverage, life insurance, an annual
medical and a financial planning allowance. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Retirement Benefits </font></font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">In 2009, each Named Executive Officer
received an RRSP contribution from the Corporation, equal to the maximum amount
allowable under the </font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-STYLE: italic"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Income Tax Act
(Canada)</font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">. In 2009,
this amount was US$20,065<font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(7)</font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">, pro-rated for Mr. Cousins, Mr. Smith
and Mr. Goldstein based on the portion of the full year they were employed by
the Corporation. None of the Named Executive Officers participate in a
Corporation-sponsored Defined Benefits Plan, Defined Contribution Plan, or
Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan, nor do they receive contributions to any
such plan on their behalf from the Corporation. In 2009, the Corporation made
changes to its overall RRSP program for 2010 and beyond. Moving forward, each
executive will be required to make a matching contribution to receive an RRSP
benefit. As a result of these changes, the maximum benefit each executive can
receive is up to 50% of the maximum amount allowable under the </font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-STYLE: italic"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Income Tax Act
(Canada)</font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">, based on
the executive making an equal matching contribution. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Total Executive Officer Compensation
</font></font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The total value of the compensation of
the Chief Executive Officer together with all of the other Named Executive
Officers (as defined below in the section entitled "Executive Compensation") was
US$3,842,113<font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(8)</font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">.</font></div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2">____________________</font></div>

      for the purpose of this disclosure using the Bank of Canada noon rate of
      exchange on December 31, 2009.</font></td>
            </tr><tr>

      <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">&#160;</font></div>
      <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">26</font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
      <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
      </div><br>
      <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Minimum Share Ownership
Guidelines</font></font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">We established executive officer minimum
share ownership guidelines in 2003, which obligate each executive officer to own
a minimum number of our Shares. Those guidelines were modified by our Board in
December 2007 to increase the minimum share ownership requirements for our
executive officers. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">For current executive officers other than
the President and Chief Executive Officer, a new minimum share ownership
guideline</font><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top; FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(9)</font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> was established requiring the executive
officers to acquire a number of Shares, equal to the lesser of: </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
        <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LINE-HEIGHT: normal; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; ">
<tr style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify;">
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
    </td>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(a)</font></td>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</td>
              <td valign="top" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">the number of Shares with a fair
      market value equal to the executive officer&#8217;s annual base salary;
    or</font></td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td colspan="3" valign="top" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;</td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(b)</font></td>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td valign="top" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">35,300
Shares.</font></td>
            </tr></table>
      </div>
      <div style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;</div>
      <div style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">In 2006, the policy for the President and
Chief Executive Officer was reviewed and the equity ownership requirement for
the President and Chief Executive Officer was increased such that the minimum
share ownership guideline is equal to the lesser of: </font></div>
      <div style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;</div>
      <div style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
        <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LINE-HEIGHT: normal; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; ">
<tr style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify;">
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
    </td>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(a)</font></td>
              <td valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</td>
              <td valign="top" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">the number of Shares that have a
      fair market value of three times the President and Chief Executive
      Officer&#8217;s base salary; or</font></td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td colspan="3" valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;</td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(b)</font></td>
              <td valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td valign="top" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">181,903
Shares.</font></td>
            </tr></table>
      </div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">For the purposes of this section, the
"fair market value" is defined as the closing price of our Shares as listed on
the TSX on the date of review of the guideline. All executive officers have met
or are on track to achieve the applicable guidelines. <br></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial">____________________</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div>
        <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LINE-HEIGHT: normal; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; ">
<tr>
              <td nowrap valign="top"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(9)</font></font></td>
              <td nowrap valign="top">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</td>
              <td valign="top" width="100%" style="BORDER-TOP: #ffffff 1pt solid; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">For executive
      officers other than the President and Chief Executive Officer who were
      employed as at December 2007, the time for acquiring the new minimum share
      ownership level has been extended by three years for a total of eight
      years. For executive officers hired after December, 2007, the minimum
      number of Shares must be acquired over a five-year period. For the
      President and Chief Executive Officer, the share acquisition period is
      five years from the date of hire.</font></td>
            </tr></table>
      </div>
      <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">&#160;</font></div>
      <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">27</font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
      <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
      </div><br>

cumulative return to a shareholder who invested $100 in our Shares on December
31, 2004, assuming reinvestment of dividends, with the total cumulative return
of $100 on the NASDAQ Composite Index for the last five years. </font></div>

      <div>&#160;</div>

compensation paid for the fiscal years ended on December 31, 2008 and December
31, 2009 to our Named Executive Officers</font><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top; FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(1)</font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">. The 2008 compensation figures have been
restated using the same foreign exchange rate as the 2009 figures to provide a
meaningful year-on-year comparison.</font></div>

        <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LINE-HEIGHT: normal; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; ">
<tr style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify;">
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(1)</font></font></td>
              <td nowrap style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</td>
              <td width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Glenn Kumoi departed as Vice
      President, Human Resources, Chief Legal Officer and Corporate Secretary
      effective August 14, 2009. His total compensation for 2009, including his
      lump sum severance payment was $630,235 converted into United States
      dollars using the Bank of Canada noon rate of exchange on December 31,
      2009.</font></td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td colspan="3" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;</td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(2)</font></font></td>
              <td nowrap style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Mr. Sheridan is also a director,
      but receives no compensation for his service as a director.</font></td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td colspan="3" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;</td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(3)</font></font></td>
              <td nowrap style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Mr. Smith resigned as Vice
      President and Chief Financial Officer effective January 30, 2009. Jay
      Murray was appointed Acting Chief Financial Officer effective January 30,
      2009 following Mr. Smith&#8217;s resignation. Bruce Cousins was appointed Vice
      President &amp; Chief Financial Officer effective April 6,
  2009.</font></td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td colspan="3" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;</td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(4)</font></font></td>
              <td nowrap style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Salary of each of the Named
      Executive Officers was paid in Canadian dollars. The Canadian dollar
      amounts for 2009 were C$511,654, C$203,885, C$41,731, C$257,337, C$299,270
      and C$228,000 for Messrs. Sheridan, Cousins, Smith, Nanji, Guzy and
      Goldstein, respectively. Note that each full-time Named Executive Officer
      voluntarily accepted a temporary 10% base salary cut starting in August
      2009. The Canadian dollar amounts for 2008 were C$530,000, C$310,000,
      C$297,692, C$310,000 for Messrs. Sheridan, Smith, Nanji and Guzy,
      respectively. The Canadian dollar amounts were converted into United
      States dollars for the purpose of the table above using the Bank of Canada
      noon rate of exchange on December 31, 2009.</font></td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td colspan="3" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;</td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(5)</font></font></td>
              <td nowrap style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The bonus of each of the Named
      Executive Officers was paid in Canadian dollars. The Canadian dollar
      amounts for 2009 were C$353,934, C$112,135, C$0, C$138,159, C$92,008 and
      C$122,183 for Messrs. Sheridan, Cousins, Smith, Nanji, Guzy and Goldstein,
      respectively. The Canadian dollar amounts for 2008 were C$681,156,
      C$221,340, C$209,797 and C$287,743 for Messrs. Sheridan, Smith, Nanji and
      Guzy, respectively. The Canadian dollar amounts were converted into United
      States dollars for the purpose of the table above using the Bank of Canada
      noon rate of exchange on December 31, 2009.</font></td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td colspan="3" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;</td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(6)</font></font></td>
              <td nowrap style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Represents the total fair market
      value of RSUs issued to each Named Executive Officer during the 2008 and
      2009 fiscal years. This amount is based on the grant date fair market
      value of the award, which equals the closing price of the Shares on the
      TSX on the date of issuance of the award. Fair value is determined in
      accordance with Section 3870 of the CICA Handbook (accounting fair value)
      is recorded as compensation expense in the statement of operations on a
      straight-line basis over vesting periods of one to three years. There is
      no difference in Canadian dollars between the grant date fair market value
      of the award and the accounting fair value. The Canadian dollar amounts
      were converted into United States dollars for the purpose of the table
      above using the Bank of Canada noon rate of exchange on December 31,
      2009.</font></td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td colspan="3" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;</td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td nowrap style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;</td>
              <td nowrap style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">As noted above, a dollar value is
      approved for the long term incentive awarded to each executive and 55% of
      this amount is awarded in the form of RSUs with the remaining 45% being
      awarded in the form of Share options in 2009. In 2008, 50% of this amount
      was awarded in the form of RSUs with the remaining 50% being awarded in
      the form of Share options. The number of RSUs awarded is equal to the
      dollar amount of the award divided by the fair market value of the Shares
      at the time of issuance (based on the closing price of the Shares on the
      TSX on the date of issuance). The number of RSUs issued to each Named
      Executive Officer in respect of the fiscal years ended December 31, 2008
      and December 31, 2009 is as follows:</font></td>
            </tr></table>
      </div>
      <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">&#160;</font></div>
      <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">29</font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></div>

              <td colspan="3" nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">_______________________</font></td>
            </tr><tr style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify;">
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">&#160;</font></td>
              <td nowrap style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;</td>
              <td width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">&#160;</font></td>
            </tr><tr style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify;">
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(A)</font></font></td>
              <td nowrap style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</td>
              <td width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The fair market value of a Share
      has been calculated using the Canadian dollar closing price of the Shares
      underlying the RSUs on the TSX on the date of issuance. The Canadian
      dollar amounts were converted to United States dollars for the purpose of
      this disclosure using the Bank of Canada noon rate of exchange on December
      31, 2009.</font></td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td nowrap style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;

      </div>
      <div style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
        <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LINE-HEIGHT: normal; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; ">
<tr style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify;">
              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(7)</font></font></td>
              <td nowrap style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</td>
              <td width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Represents the total of the fair
      market value of options to purchase our Shares issued under the Option
      Plan granted to each Named Executive Officer during each fiscal year.
      There were no options that were amended or modified during 2008 or 2009.
      This amount is based on the grant date fair market value of the award
      determined using the Black-Scholes valuation model using the following key
      assumptions: expected life of 5 years, expected volatility of 60% and risk
      free interest rate of 2% for 2009 and expected life of 7 years, expected
      volatility of 46% and risk free interest rate of 4% for 2008. Accounting
      fair value is recorded as compensation expense in the statement of
      operations on a straight-line basis over the vesting period. There is no
      difference in Canadian dollars between the grant date fair market value of
      the award determined using the Black-Scholes valuation model and
      accounting fair value determined in accordance with s.3870 of the CICA
      Handbook (accounting fair value). The Canadian dollar amounts were
      converted into United States dollars for the purpose of the table above
      using the Bank of Canada noon rate of exchange on December 31,
    2009.</font></td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td colspan="3" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160; </td>
            </tr><tr>
              <td nowrap style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">&#160;</td>
              <td nowrap style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
              </td>
              <td width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">As noted above, a dollar value is
      approved for the long term incentive awarded to each executive and 55% of
      this amount is awarded in the form of RSUs with the remaining 45% being
      awarded in the form of Share options. In 2008, 50% of this amount was
      awarded in the form of RSUs with the remaining 50% being awarded in the
      form of Share options. The number of Share options awarded is equal to the
      dollar amount of the award divided by the fair market value of the Shares
      at the time of issuance (based on the closing trading price of the Shares
      on the TSX on the day prior to issuance). The number of Share options
      issued to each Named Executive Officer in respect of the fiscal years
      ended December 31, 2008 and December 31, 2009 is as
  follows:</font></td>
            </tr></table>
      </div>

              <td nowrap valign="top" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">(8)</font></font></td>

              <td valign="top" width="100%" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">All Other Compensation was actually
      paid in Canadian dollars. The Canadian dollar amounts for 2009 were
      C$44,610, C$60,038, C$35,341, C$92,628, C$42,890 and C$203,501 for Messrs.
      Sheridan, Cousins, Smith, Nanji, Guzy and Goldstein, respectively. The
      Canadian dollar amounts for 2008 were C$48,051, C$51,524, C$40,828 and
      C$60,235 for Messrs. Sheridan, Smith, Nanji and Guzy, respectively. The
