    </div><br>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">All significant intercompany balances and
transactions have been eliminated on consolidation. </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="center"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"><font size="2">11</font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
    <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
    </div><br>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="">
<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">BALLARD POWER SYSTEMS
  INC.</font></font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(Tabular amounts expressed in thousands of U.S. dollars, except per
      share amounts and number of shares)</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">&#160; </td>
          </tr></table>
    </div><br>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">1.</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Nature of business and summary of
significant accounting policies (cont&#8217;d): </font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(e) Translation
of foreign currencies: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The measurement currency of the
Corporation is the U.S. dollar. Transactions in foreign currencies are
translated at the exchange rate in effect at the transaction date. Monetary
assets and liabilities denominated in other than the measurement currency are
translated at the exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date. The
resulting exchange gains and losses are recognized in earnings.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(f) Revenue
recognition: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation generates revenues
primarily from product sales and services. Revenues are also earned by providing
engineering development services. Product revenues are derived primarily from
standard equipment and material sales contracts and from long-term fixed price
contracts. Service revenues are derived primarily from cost-plus reimbursable
contracts. Engineering development revenues are derived primarily from long-term
fixed price contracts.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">On standard equipment and material sales
contracts, revenues are recorded when the product is shipped to the customer and
the risks of ownership are transferred to the customer, when the price is fixed
and determinable, and collection is reasonably assured. Provisions are made at
the time of sale for warranties.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">On cost-plus reimbursable contracts,
revenues are recognized as costs are incurred, and include applicable fees
earned as services are provided.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">On long-term fixed price contracts,
revenues are recognized on the percentage-of-completion basis over the duration
of the contract, which consists of recognizing revenue on a given contract
proportionately with its percentage of completion at any given time. The
percentage of completion is determined by dividing the cumulative costs incurred
as at the balance sheet date by the sum of incurred and anticipated costs for
completing a contract.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The cumulative effect of changes to
anticipated revenues and anticipated costs for completing a contract are
recognized in the period in which the revisions are identified. In the event
that the anticipated costs exceed the anticipated revenues on a contract, such
loss is recognized in its entirety in the period it becomes known.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Deferred revenue represents cash received
from customers in excess of revenue recognized on uncompleted
contracts.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(g) Cash, cash
equivalents and short-term investments: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Cash and cash equivalents consist of cash
on deposit and highly liquid short-term interest-bearing securities with
maturities at the date of purchase of three months or less.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Short-term investments consist of highly
liquid interest bearing securities with maturities at the date of purchase
between three months and three years.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">12</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
    <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
    </div><br>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="">
<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">BALLARD POWER SYSTEMS
  INC.</font></font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(Tabular amounts expressed in thousands of U.S. dollars, except per
      share amounts and number of shares)</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">&#160; </td>
          </tr></table>
    </div><br>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">1.</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Nature of business and summary of
significant accounting policies (cont&#8217;d): </font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(h) Financial
instruments:</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation measures its financial
assets in the balance sheet at fair value, except for loans and receivables,
which are measured at amortized cost. Financial liabilities classified as held
for trading, including derivatives, are measured in the balance sheet at fair
value; all other financial liabilities are measured at amortized cost. Long-term
investments are measured at cost as they are privately held
entities.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Measurement in subsequent periods depends
on whether the financial instrument has been classified as held for trading,
available-for-sale, held-to-maturity, loans and receivables, or other
liabilities. The Corporation classifies its accounts receivables as loans and
receivables and its accounts payable and warranty liabilities as other financial
liabilities.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Periodically, the Corporation enters into
forward exchange contracts to limit its exposure to foreign currency rate
fluctuations and to platinum price fluctuations. </font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">These derivative contracts are recorded
as either assets or liabilities in the consolidated balance sheet at fair value.
Any changes in fair value are recognized in net income. The Corporation does not
designate its financial instruments as hedges. </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(i) Inventories:
</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Inventories are recorded at the lower of
cost and net realizable value. The cost of inventories is based on the first-in
first-out principle, and includes expenditures incurred in acquiring the
inventories, production or conversion costs, and other costs incurred in
bringing them to their existing location and condition. In the case of
manufactured inventories and work in progress, cost includes materials, labor
and the appropriate share of production overhead based on normal operating
capacity. Costs of materials are determined on an average per unit basis. Net
realizable value is the estimated selling price in the ordinary course of
business, less the estimated costs of completion and selling expenses. In
establishing the appropriate inventory obsolescence provision, management
estimates the likelihood that inventory carrying values will be affected by
changes in market demand, technology and design, which could make inventory on
hand recoverable at less than its cost or even obsolete.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">13</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
    <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
    </div><br>
    <div>

  INC.</font></font></td>

            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(Tabular amounts expressed in thousands of U.S. dollars, except per
      share amounts and number of shares)</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">&#160; </td>
          </tr></table>
    </div><br>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">1.</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Nature of business and summary of
significant accounting policies (cont&#8217;d): </font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(j) Property,
plant and equipment: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Property, plant and equipment are
initially recorded at cost and are amortized from the date of acquisition or, in
respect of internally constructed assets, from the time an asset is completed
and ready for use, using the straight-line method over the estimated useful
lives of the assets as follows: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="right">
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="97%" style="LINE-HEIGHT: 14pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; ">
<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="65%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-TOP: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Buildings</font></td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="34%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-TOP: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">30 to 39
      years</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="65%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Computer equipment</font></td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="34%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">3 to 7&#160;years</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="65%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Furniture and fixtures</font></td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="34%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">5 to 14 years</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="65%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Leasehold improvements</font></td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="34%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The shorter of initial term of the respective</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="65%">&#160;</td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="34%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">lease and estimated useful life</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="65%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Production and test
    equipment</font></td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="34%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">4 to 15 years</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="65%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Production and test equipment under</font></td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="34%">&#160;</td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="65%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">capital
      lease</font></td>
            <td nowrap width="34%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid; TEXT-ALIGN: right"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">5
  years</font></td>
          </tr></table>
    </div><br>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(k) Intangible
assets: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Intangible assets consist of fuel cell
technology acquired from third parties and are recorded at cost. Intangible
assets are amortized over their estimated useful lives of 5 to 15 years using
the straight-line method.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Costs incurred in establishing and
maintaining patents and license agreements are expensed in the period incurred.
</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(l) Impairment
of long-lived assets:</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Long-lived assets, including property,
plant and equipment, investments, and intangible assets, are reviewed for
impairment when events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying
amount of the asset may not be recoverable. An impairment loss, if any, is
recognized when the carrying amount of a long-lived asset exceeds its fair value
based on its estimated undiscounted future cash flows.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(m)
Goodwill:</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Goodwill represents the excess of the
purchase price of an acquired enterprise over the fair value assigned to assets
acquired and liabilities assumed.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">14</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
    <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
    </div><br>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="">
<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">BALLARD POWER SYSTEMS
  INC.</font></font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(Tabular amounts expressed in thousands of U.S. dollars, except per
      share amounts and number of shares)</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">&#160; </td>
          </tr></table>
    </div><br>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">1.</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Nature of business and summary of
significant accounting policies (cont&#8217;d): </font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(m) Goodwill
(cont&#8217;d): </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Goodwill is assessed for impairment at
least annually, or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances
indicate that the goodwill might be impaired. The assessment of impairment is
based on estimated fair market values derived from certain valuation models,
which may consider various factors such as normalized and estimated future
earnings, price earnings multiples, terminal values and discount rates. An
impairment loss, if any, is recognized to the extent that the carrying amount of
goodwill exceeds its estimated fair market value.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation has designated December
31 as the date for the annual impairment test. As at December 31, 2009, date of
the last impairment test, goodwill was not considered to be
impaired.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(n) Investments:
</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Investments in shares of companies over
which the Corporation has the ability to exercise significant influence are
accounted for by the equity method. Investments in companies where significant
influence does not exist are carried at cost. </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(o) Accrued
warranty liabilities: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">A provision for warranty costs is
recorded on product sales at the time of shipment. In establishing the accrued
warranty liability, management estimates the likelihood that products sold will
experience warranty claims and the estimated cost to resolve claims received,
taking into account the nature of the contract and past and projected experience
with the products. </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(p)
Leases:</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Leases are classified as capital or
operating depending upon the terms and conditions of the contracts. Leases,
which transfer substantially all the benefits and risks incident to ownership of
the leased property to the Corporation, are accounted for as capital leases. The
cost of assets under capital leases represent the present value of minimum lease
payments and are amortized on a straight-line basis over the lease term. Assets
under capital leases are presented in property, plant and equipment in the
consolidated balance sheet.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Leases that do not transfer substantially
all of the benefits and risks incident to ownership of the property are
accounted for as operating leases.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">15</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
    <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
    </div><br>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="">
<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">BALLARD POWER SYSTEMS
  INC.</font></font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(Tabular amounts expressed in thousands of U.S. dollars, except per
      share amounts and number of shares)</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">&#160; </td>
          </tr></table>
    </div><br>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">1.</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Nature of business and summary of
significant accounting policies (cont&#8217;d): </font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(q) Asset
retirement obligations:</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Legal obligations to retire tangible
long-lived assets are recorded at fair value at acquisition with a corresponding
increase in asset value. These include assets leased under operating leases. The
liability is accreted over the life of the asset to fair value and the increase
in asset value is depreciated over the remaining useful life of the asset.
</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(r) Research and
product development costs:</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Research costs are expensed as they are
incurred. Product development costs are expensed as incurred except if the costs
are related to the development and setup of new products, processes and systems
and satisfy certain conditions for capitalization, including reasonable
assurance that they will be recovered. All capitalized development costs, if
any, are amortized when commercial production begins, using the straight-line
method over a period of five years. An impairment loss, if any, is recognized in
the period it occurs.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">As at December 31, 2009, the Corporation
has not capitalized any development costs.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(s) Income
taxes: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation follows the asset and
liability method of accounting for income taxes. Under this method, future
income taxes are recognized for the future income tax consequences attributable
to differences between the financial statement carrying values of assets and
liabilities and their respective income tax bases (temporary differences) and
for loss carry-forwards. The resulting changes in the net future tax asset or
liability are included in income. Future tax assets and liabilities are measured
using enacted, or substantively enacted, tax rates expected to apply to taxable
income in the years in which temporary differences are expected to be recovered
or settled.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The effect on future income tax assets
and liabilities, of a change in tax rates, is included in income in the period
that includes the substantive enactment date. Future income tax assets are
evaluated, and if realization is not considered to be &#8220;more likely than not,&#8221; a
valuation allowance is provided.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">16</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
    <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
    </div><br>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; ">
<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">BALLARD POWER SYSTEMS
      INC.</font></font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(Tabular amounts expressed in thousands of U.S. dollars, except per
      share amounts and number of shares)</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">&#160;</td>
          </tr></table>
    </div><br>
    <div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">1.</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Nature of business and summary of
significant accounting policies (cont&#8217;d): </font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="left"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(t) Employee future
benefits: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt; WIDTH: 100%">
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation
accounts for employee future benefit plan assets and obligations and related
costs of defined benefit pension plans, and other post-retirement benefits,
under the following accounting policies:</font></div>
      <ul style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; MARGIN-LEFT: 16px; TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
        <li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Accrued benefit obligations
  and the cost of pension and other post-retirement benefits earned by
  participants are determined from actuarial calculations according to the
  projected benefit method prorated on services. The accrued benefit obligations
  under the post-employment benefit plans are determined from actuarial
  calculations according to the accumulated benefit method. The calculations are
  based on management&#8217;s best estimate assumptions relating to salary
  escalations, retirement age of participants and estimated health-care costs.
  Pension obligations are discounted using current market interest rates.
  </font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Changes in accrued benefit
  obligations are recognized immediately.<br>&#160;</font>
          </li>
        <li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Plan assets are measured at
  fair value, determined directly by reference to quoted market prices. Changes
  in fair value on plan assets are recognized immediately.<br>&#160;</font>
          </li>
        <li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Actuarial gains or losses
  arise from changes in actuarial assumptions used to determine accrued benefit
  obligations and from emerging experience different from the selected
  assumptions. Actuarial gains or losses are recognized
  immediately.<br>&#160;</font>
          </li>
        <li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Current service costs are
  recognized immediately.<br>&#160;</font>
          </li>
        <li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Curtailment gains and losses
  arising from plan amendments are recognized immediately.</font> </li>
      </ul>
      <div style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The cost of defined contribution pension plans, which cover our employees
in Canada and the United States, are expensed, as contributions are
due.</font></div>
    </div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(u) Share-based
compensation:</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt; WIDTH: 100%">
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation
used the fair-value based method of accounting for share-based compensation for
all awards of shares and share options granted. The fair value at the grant date
of share options (&#8220;options&#8221;) is calculated using the Black-Scholes valuation
method. The fair value of restricted share units (&#8220;RSUs&#8221;) and deferred share
units (&#8220;DSUs&#8221;) are measured based on the fair value of the underlying shares on
the grant date. Compensation expense is charged to net income over the vesting
period and is recognized when services are received with a corresponding
increase to contributed surplus. The Corporation estimates forfeitures at the
grant date and revises the estimate as necessary if subsequent information
indicates that actual forfeitures differ significantly from the original
estimate.</font></div>
    </div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">17</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
    <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
    </div><br>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; ">
<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">BALLARD POWER SYSTEMS
      INC.</font></font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(Tabular amounts expressed in thousands of U.S. dollars, except per
      share amounts and number of shares)</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">&#160;</td>
          </tr></table>
    </div><br>
    <div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">1.</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Nature of business and summary of
significant accounting policies (cont&#8217;d): </font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="left"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(u) Share-based
compensation (cont&#8217;d):</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation issues shares and share
options under its share-based compensation plans as described in note 13. Any
consideration paid by employees on exercise of share options or purchase of
shares, together with the amount initially recorded in contributed surplus, is
credited to share capital. </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="left"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(v) Earnings (loss)
per share: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Basic earnings (loss) per share is
computed using the weighted average number of common shares outstanding during
the year. Diluted earnings per share is calculated using the treasury stock
method. Under the treasury stock method, the dilution is calculated based upon
the number of common shares issued should deferred share units (&#8220;DSUs&#8221;),
restricted share units (&#8220;RSUs&#8221;), and &#8220;in the money&#8221; options, if any, be
exercised. For the year ended December 31, 2009, diluted loss per share has not
been calculated, as the effects of outstanding stock-based compensation
arrangements would be anti-dilutive.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="left"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(w) Comprehensive
income (loss):</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Other comprehensive income (loss)
represents changes in shareholders&#8217; equity and includes items such as unrealized
gains and losses on financial assets classified as available-for-sale, and
cumulative translation adjustments. The Corporation has included a
reconciliation of comprehensive income and accumulated other comprehensive
income, which is presented as a separate category of shareholders&#8217; equity, on
the consolidated balance sheet and the consolidated statement of shareholders&#8217;
equity.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="left"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(x) Government
assistance and investment tax credits: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Government assistance and investment tax
credits are recorded as either a reduction of the cost of the applicable assets,
or credited against the related expense incurred in the statement of operations,
as determined by the terms and conditions of the agreements under which the
assistance is provided to the Corporation or the nature of the expenditures
which gave rise to the credits. Government assistance and investment tax credit
receivables are recorded when their receipt is reasonably assured. </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="left"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(y) Comparative
figures: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Certain comparative figures have been
reclassified to conform with the presentation adopted for the current
year.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">18</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
    <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
    </div><br>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; ">
<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">BALLARD POWER SYSTEMS
      INC.</font></font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(Tabular amounts expressed in thousands of U.S. dollars, except per
      share amounts and number of shares)</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">&#160;</td>
          </tr></table>
    </div><br>
    <div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">2.</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif"> </font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Non-dilutive financing:
</font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt; WIDTH: 100%">
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">On December 31,
2008, the Corporation completed a restructuring transaction with Superior Plus
Income Fund (&#8220;Superior Plus&#8221;) to reorganize the Corporation&#8217;s business under a
Plan of Arrangement (the &#8220;Arrangement&#8221;). Pursuant to the Arrangement, Superior
Plus transferred $38,029,000 (CDN $46,319,000) to the Corporation&#8217;s parent
company (&#8220;Old Ballard&#8221;). Old Ballard subsequently transferred all of its assets
and liabilities (including the net cash proceeds, but excluding Old Ballard&#8217;s
historic Canadian income tax carry forward attributes), to a new wholly owned
company, (&#8220;the Corporation&#8221;). Old Ballard&#8217;s shareholders exchanged their shares,
on a one-for-one basis, for shares of the Corporation. The Corporation is
carrying on the full scope of Old Ballard&#8217;s business operations, and holds all
rights to intellectual property, as held by Old Ballard before the completion of
the Arrangement.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">As such, all
references to the Corporation in these Consolidated Financial Statements include
Old Ballard for matters occurring before the Arrangement.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">As the transfer
of the business assets, liabilities and operations from Old Ballard to the
Corporation represented a transaction with no change in shareholder ownership,
the transaction was accounted for using continuity of interest
accounting.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Pursuant to
continuity of interest accounting, the assets transferred and liabilities
assumed were recorded at their carrying values as reported by Old Ballard
immediately prior to the completion of the Arrangement. As a result, the net
cash proceeds were recorded as a credit to shareholders&#8217; equity.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">In addition, as
the future income tax benefits of Old Ballard&#8217;s Canadian non-capital losses,
capital losses, scientific research and development expenditures and investment
tax credits generated through to the date of the completion of the Arrangement
are not available to the Corporation after the completion of the Arrangement on
December 31, 2008. The gross future income tax assets related to these Canadian
tax pools as of December 31, 2008 was reduced to nil, with a corresponding
reduction of the related valuation allowance (note 16).</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LINE-HEIGHT: 14pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; ">
<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="94%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-TOP: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Proceeds of
      Arrangement on December 31, 2008</font></td>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="1%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-TOP: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">$&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</font></td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="3%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-TOP: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">38,029</font></td>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="1%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-TOP: #000000 1.5pt solid">
            </td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="94%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Disposal costs
      paid to December 31, 2008</font></td>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="1%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid">
            </td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="3%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(1,109</font></td>

    <div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">3. Disposition of certain automotive fuel
cell assets:</font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt; WIDTH: 100%">
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">On January 31,
2008, the Corporation completed the sale of its automotive fuel cell research
and development assets (the &#8220;AFCC Transaction&#8221;) to Daimler AG (&#8220;Daimler&#8221;), Ford
Motor Company (&#8220;Ford&#8221;) and a newly created private corporation, AFCC Automotive
Fuel Cell Cooperation Corp. (&#8220;AFCC&#8221;). AFCC was created to carry on the
development of automotive fuel cells for Daimler and Ford. Under the terms of
the AFCC Transaction, the Corporation transferred to Daimler, Ford and AFCC its
automotive patents, automotive fuel cell test equipment, automotive fuel cell
inventory, $60,000,000 in cash, the automotive fuel cell warranty liabilities,
all automotive fuel cell development contracts between Ballard, Daimler and
Ford, 80.1% of the outstanding shares of AFCC (note 8), 112 personnel and
related office equipment and a royalty free, sub-licensable license to the
remaining Ballard intellectual property for use in automotive applications. In
exchange, Daimler and Ford returned to the Corporation an aggregate of
34,261,298 of its common shares valued at $173,900,000, one Class A share and
one Class B share, collectively representing Daimler and Ford&#8217;s entire direct
and indirect equity interest in the Corporation. These shares were then
cancelled. </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation
recorded a gain of $96,845,000 on the closing of the AFCC transaction on January
31, 2008.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LINE-HEIGHT: 14pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; ">

as cost of product and service revenues amounted to $20,677,000 (2008 -
$25,948,000). In 2009, the write-down of inventories to net realizable value
amounted to $874,000 (2008 - $745,000). There were no reversals of write-downs
in 2009 or 2008. Write-downs and reversals are included in either cost of
product and service revenues, or research and product development expense,
depending on the nature of inventory.</font></div>

    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">6. Property, plant and equipment:
</font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt; WIDTH: 100%">
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LINE-HEIGHT: 14pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; ">
<tr valign="bottom">

      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; ">

            </td>
          </tr></table><br>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Chrysalix Energy
Limited Partnership (&#8220;Chrysalix&#8221;) is recorded at the lower of cost and estimated
net realizable value. During 2009, the Corporation made additional investments
of $200,000 (2008 - $273,000) in Chrysalix, which was offset by a cash
distribution received from Chrysalix of $68,000 (2008 - $nil). In 2008, an
impairment charge of $3,020,000 was recorded to adjust the carrying value of
Chrysalix to its estimated net realizable value.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation
maintains a 19.9% interest in AFCC, which is accounted for using the cost method
and is subject to a Share Purchase Agreement (&#8220;SPA&#8221;) under which Ford, either at
the option of the Corporation or Ford&#8217;s election, may purchase the Corporation&#8217;s
interest in AFCC at any time after January 31, 2013 for $65,000,000 plus
interest accruing at LIBOR form January 31, 2008. The Corporation has no
obligation to fund any of AFCC&#8217;s operating expenses. On the disposition of
automotive fuel cell assets on the closing of the AFCC Transaction (note 3), the
SPA was considered to be a derivative instrument and was recorded at its fair
value of $1.</font></div>
    </div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">22</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
    <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
    </div><br>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; ">
<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">BALLARD POWER SYSTEMS
      INC.</font></font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(Tabular amounts expressed in thousands of U.S. dollars, except per
      share amounts and number of shares)</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">&#160;</td>
          </tr></table>
    </div><br>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">8. Investments (cont&#8217;d):
</font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt; WIDTH: 100%">
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">In December
2009, the Corporation completed an agreement to monetize its rights under the
SPA. On the monetization of the SPA, the Corporation effectively sold its rights
and obligations under the SPA to a third party for initial fixed proceeds of
$37,000,000 and a contingent payment of $7,500,000, due in January 2013. The
contingent payment is subject to the third party&#8217;s rights in the transaction
remaining unsubordinated.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation
recorded a gain of $34,297,000 on the closing of the SPA monetization in 2009
reflecting the initial proceeds received net of disposal costs and a write-down
of its investment in AFCC to a nominal value.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>

      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">In August 2009,
the Corporation completed an organizational restructuring resulting in
restructuring and related charges of $4,866,000 primarily for severance expense
on the elimination of 85 positions. This action was in addition to an
organizational restructuring completed in March 2009 that resulted in
restructuring and related charges of $1,363,000 primarily for severance expense
on the elimination of 32 positions. As at December 31, 2009, $2,137,000 of
restructuring and related costs were payable.</font></div>

    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">10. Obligations under capital
lease:</font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt; WIDTH: 100%">
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation
leases certain production and test equipment under a capital lease expiring in
December 2014. Under the terms of the lease, the Corporation must either (i)
purchase the equipment in December 2014 for its residual value equal to 20% of
the initial cost, or (ii) enter into a new lease agreement for the residual
value. Minimum future lease payments are as follows: </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LINE-HEIGHT: 14pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; ">

      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">In determining
the fair value of the asset retirement obligations, the estimated future cash
flows have been discounted at 12% per annum. The total undiscounted amount of
the estimated cash flows required to settle this obligation is $3,988,000. The
obligation will be settled at the end of the term of the operating lease, which
extends to 2019.</font></div>

<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">BALLARD POWER SYSTEMS
      INC.</font></font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</font></td>

    </div><br>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">11. Long-term liabilities (cont&#8217;d):
</font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">In March 2009, the Corporation made a net
investment of $5,000,000 (2008 - $5,939,000), in EBARA BALLARD Corporation
(&#8220;EBARA BALLARD&#8221;). In May 2009, the Corporation announced intentions to
discontinue operations in EBARA BALLARD, a joint venture with EBARA Corporation
(&#8220;Ebara&#8221;) that was focused on the development, manufacture, sale, and servicing
of stationary power systems for the residential cogeneration market in Japan.
EBARA BALLARD was accounted for using the equity method and was considered a
related party. On the announcement of the intention to discontinue operations,
the $10,838,000 of historic recorded equity losses in EBARA BALLARD in excess of
the net investment of EBARA BALLARD (including $2,474,000 of equity losses
recorded in 2009 prior to the wind-up), was reversed to net income as (i) Ebara
was solely responsible for the liquidation obligations of EBARA BALLARD; and
(ii) the Corporation was not committed to provide, nor did it intend to provide,
any further financial support to EBARA BALLARD. EBARA BALLARD was formally
dissolved in October 2009. As a result, the Corporation recorded equity income
of $8,364,000 in 2009 and an equity loss of $8,649,000 in 2008.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>

          </tr></table><br>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation
maintains a defined benefit pension plan covering employees in the United
States. The benefits under the pension plan are based on years of service and
salary levels accrued as of December 31, 2009. In 2009, amendments were made to
the defined benefit pension plan to freeze benefits accruing to employees at
their respective years of service and salary levels obtained as of December 31,
2009. This hard freeze of pension plan benefits resulted in the recognition of
curtailment gains of $1,055,000 in 2009. Certain employees in the United States
are also eligible for post-retirement healthcare, life insurance and other
benefits. The Corporation accrues its obligations under employee future benefit
plans and the related costs, net of the fair value of plan
assets.</font></div>
    </div>

    </div><br>

            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(Tabular amounts expressed in thousands of U.S. dollars, except per
      share amounts and number of shares)</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">&#160;</td>
          </tr></table>
    </div><br>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">12. Employee future benefit plans
(cont&#8217;d): </font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt; WIDTH: 100%">
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The measurement
date used to determine pension and other post-retirement benefit measures is
December 31 of each year. The most recent actuarial valuation of the employee
future benefit plans for funding purposes was as of January 1, 2009. The next
actuarial valuation of the employee future benefit plans for funding purposes is
expected to be as of January 1, 2010.</font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>
      <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Information
about the Corporation&#8217;s employee future benefit plans, in aggregate, is as
follows: </font></div>
      <div>&#160;</div>

    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The significant actuarial assumptions
adopted in determining net expense for the years ended December 31, 2009 and
2008 were as follows: </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="LINE-HEIGHT: 14pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; ">
<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="1%">
            </td>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="79%" style="BORDER-TOP: #000000 1.5pt solid; BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid">
            </td>
            <td nowrap width="1%" style="BORDER-TOP: #000000 1.5pt solid; BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid">
            </td>
            <td colspan="3" nowrap width="9%" style="BORDER-TOP: #000000 1.5pt solid; BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid; TEXT-ALIGN: center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">2009</font></td>

    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">12. Employee future benefit plans
(cont&#8217;d): </font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">A one-percentage-point change in assumed
health care cost trend rates would not have a material impact on the
Corporation&#8217;s financial statements. </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>

            <td valign="top">&#160;</td>
            <td align="left" valign="top" width="100%">
              <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">In 2009,
      the Corporation adopted a consolidated share option plan to supersede and
      replace four previous share option plans. All directors, officers and
      employees of the Corporation, and its subsidiaries, are eligible to
      participate in the share option plan although as a matter of policy,
      options are currently not issued to directors. Option exercise prices are
      denominated in both Canadian and U.S. dollars, depending on the residency
      of the recipient. Canadian dollar denominated options have been converted
      to U.S. dollars using the year-end exchange rate for presentation
      purposes. All options have a term of seven to ten years from the date of
      grant unless otherwise determined by the board of directors. One-third of
      the options vest and may be exercised, at the beginning of each of the
      second, third and fourth years after granting.</font></div>
            </td>

            <td align="right" nowrap width="1%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">
            </td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="4%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">4.7</font></td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="1%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">
            </td>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="1%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">$</font></td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="3%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">19.18</font></td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="1%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">
            </td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="3%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">3,423,397</font></td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="1%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">
            </td>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="1%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">$</font></td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="3%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">31.02</font></td>
          </tr></table>
    </div><br>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 30pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation uses the fair-value
method for recording employee and director share option grants. During 2009,
compensation expense of $1,760,000 (2008 - $2,763,000) was recorded in net
income as a result of fair value accounting for share options granted. The share
options granted during the year had a weighted average fair value of $0.76 (2008
- - $2.65) and vesting periods of three years. </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 30pt" align="left"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The fair values of the options granted were determined using the
Black-Scholes valuation model under the following weighted average assumptions:

      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="">
<tr>
            <td nowrap valign="top">
            </td>
            <td nowrap valign="top"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(c)</font></td>
            <td nowrap valign="top">&#160;</td>
            <td valign="top" width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Share distribution plan:</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td nowrap>
            </td>
            <td colspan="3" valign="top" width="100%">&#160;</td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td nowrap>&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</td>
            <td nowrap valign="top">
            </td>
            <td nowrap valign="top">
            </td>
            <td align="left" valign="top" width="100%">
              <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">In 2009,
      the Corporation adopted a consolidated share distribution plan to
      supersede and replace five previous share distribution plans. The
      consolidated share distribution plan permits the issuance of common shares
      for no cash consideration to employees of the Corporation to recognize
      their past contribution and to encourage future contribution to the
      Corporation. At December 31, 2009, there were 1,472,380 shares available
      to be issued under these plans.</font></div>
            </td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td nowrap>
            </td>
            <td colspan="3" valign="top" width="100%">&#160;</td>
          </tr><tr>

            <td nowrap valign="top">
            </td>
            <td align="left" valign="top" width="100%">
              <div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">No
      compensation expense was charged against income during the year ended
      December 31, 2009 (2008 - $5,446,000) for shares distributed, and to be
      distributed, under the plans.</font></div>
            </td>
          </tr></table>

<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">BALLARD POWER SYSTEMS
      INC.</font></font></td>

    </div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">13. Share capital (cont&#8217;d):
</font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify; ">
<tr>
            <td nowrap valign="top">
            </td>
            <td nowrap valign="top"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(d)</font></td>
            <td nowrap valign="top">&#160;</td>
            <td valign="top" width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Deferred Share Units:</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td>
            </td>
            <td colspan="3" valign="top">&#160;</td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td>
            </td>
            <td valign="top">&#160;</td>
            <td valign="top">
            </td>
            <td valign="top" width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Deferred share units (&#8220;DSUs&#8221;) are granted to the board of directors
      and executives. Eligible directors may elect to receive all or part of
      their annual retainers and executives may elect to receive all or part of
      their annual bonuses in DSUs. Each DSU is redeemable for one common share
      in the capital of the Corporation after the director or executive ceases
      to provide services to the Corporation. Shares will be issued from the
      Corporation&#8217;s share distribution plan. As at December 31, 2009, 316,152
      DSUs (2008 &#8211; 333,066) were issued and outstanding.</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td>
            </td>
            <td colspan="3" valign="top">&#160;</td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td>
            </td>
            <td valign="top">&#160;</td>
            <td valign="top">
            </td>
            <td valign="top" width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">In 2009, the Corporation determined that 169,276 DSUs had been
      issued to directors in excess of a limitation set out in its share
      distribution plan. The Corporation&#8217;s shareholders ratified the DSU
      overgrant. Accordingly the previously recorded compensation expense
      relating to the overgrant was reversed from contributed surplus and the
      revised compensation expense for the approved DSUs was recorded based on
      the market price of the shares on the date of approval, resulting in a net
      decrease to contributed surplus of $451,000. In 2008, $202,000 of
      compensation expense was recorded for the year then ended.</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td>
            </td>
            <td colspan="3" valign="top">&#160;</td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td nowrap valign="top">
            </td>
            <td nowrap valign="top"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(e)</font></td>
            <td nowrap valign="top">
            </td>
            <td valign="top" width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Restricted Share Units:</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td>
            </td>
            <td colspan="3" valign="top">&#160;</td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td>
            </td>
            <td valign="top">&#160;</td>
            <td valign="top">
            </td>
            <td valign="top" width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation has two plans under which restricted share units
      (&#8220;RSUs&#8221;) may be granted. The awards under the consolidated share
      distribution plan (note 13 (c)) are satisfied by the issuance of treasury
      shares on maturity. The awards granted under the Market Purchase RSU Plan
      are satisfied by shares to be purchased on the open market by a trust
      established for that purpose. During 2009, the Corporation repurchased
      87,729 common shares through the trust for cash consideration of $207,000
      for the purpose of funding future grants under the Market Purchase RSU
      Plan.</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td>
            </td>
            <td colspan="3" valign="top">&#160;</td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td>&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</td>
            <td valign="top">&#160;</td>
            <td valign="top">
            </td>
            <td valign="top" width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">RSUs are granted to employees and executives. Each RSU is
      convertible into one common share. The RSUs vest after a specified number
      of years from the date of issuance, and under certain circumstances, are
      contingent on achieving specified performance criteria. As at December 31,
      2009, 1,621,749 RSUs (2008 &#8211; 1,092,813) were issued and outstanding, and
      $1,736,000 (2008 - $1,388,000) of compensation expense was recorded for
      the year then ended.</font></td>
          </tr></table>
    </div>
    <div>&#160;</div>

    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation has agreed to pay
royalties in respect of sales of certain fuel cell-based stationary power
products under two development programs with Canadian government agencies. The
total combined royalty is limited in any year to 4% of revenue from such
products. Under the original terms of the Utilities Development Program (Phase
1) with the Governments of Canada and British Columbia, total royalties were
payable to a maximum equal to the original amount of the government
contributions of CDN $10,702,000. During 2009, a Canadian government agency
agreed to terminate potential royalties payable of CDN $5,351,000 in respect of
future sales of fuel cell based stationary power products under the Utilities
Development Program (Phase 1). As at December 31, 2009, no royalties have been
incurred for Phase 1. Under the terms of the Utilities Development Program
(Phase 2) with Technology Partnerships Canada (&#8220;TPC&#8221;) total royalties are
payable to a maximum of CDN $38,329,000. As at December 31, 2009, a total of CDN
$5,320,000 in royalty repayments have been made for Phase 2 including payments
of CDN $115,000 in 2009 and CDN $184,000 in 2008.</font></div>

    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation has issued letter of
credits in the amount of $293,000 (2008 - $nil) related to inventory purchases
and customer guarantees as at December 31, 2009.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">At December 31, 2009, the Corporation has
outstanding commitments aggregating up to a maximum of $1,691,000 (2008 -
$164,000) relating primarily to purchases of property, plant and
equipment.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation is also committed to make
future investments totaling $255,000 in Chrysalix (note 8). </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Corporation has agreed to pay
royalties in respect of sales of Ballard fuel cells or fuel cell systems under a
July 31, 1996 Fuel Cell Bus Program Agreement (&#8220;FC Bus Agreement&#8221;), with
Province of British Columbia, BC Transit, and BC Transportation Financing
Authority (&#8220;BCTFA&#8221;). Under the terms of FC Bus Agreement, the royalty payable is
at a rate of 2% on future sales of such products for commercial transit
application to a maximum of $2,093,000 (CDN$ 2,200,000). No royalties have been
paid, or accrued, as of December 31, 2009.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Arrangement with Superior Plus (note
2) includes an indemnification agreement dated December 31, 2008 (the &#8220;Indemnity
Agreement&#8221;), which sets out the parties&#8217; continuing obligations to the other.
The Indemnity Agreement provides for the indemnification by each of the parties
to the other for breaches of representations and warranties or covenants, as
well as, in the Corporation&#8217;s case, any liability relating to the business,
which is suffered by Superior Plus. The Corporation&#8217;s indemnity to Superior Plus
with respect to representation relating to the existence of the Corporation&#8217;s
tax pools immediately prior to the completion of the Arrangement is limited to
an aggregate of $6,993,000 (CDN $7,350,000) with a threshold amount of $476,000
(CDN $500,000) before there is an obligation to make a payment. The Indemnity
Agreement also provides for adjustments to be paid by the Corporation, or to the
Corporation, depending on the final determination of the amount of 2008 Canadian
non-capital losses, scientific research and development expenditures and
investment tax credits, to the extent that such amounts are more or less than
the amounts estimated at the time the Arrangement was executed.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">32 </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
    <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
    </div><br>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; ">
<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">BALLARD POWER SYSTEMS
      INC.</font></font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements </font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(Tabular amounts expressed in thousands of U.S. dollars, except per
      share amounts and number of shares)</font></td>
          </tr><tr>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="100%" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: arial">&#160;</font></td>
          </tr></table>
    </div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial">15. Commitments, guarantees and contingencies
(cont&#8217;d):</font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial">At December 31, 2009, no amount payable or receivable has been accrued as
a result of the Indemnity Agreement.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial">16. Income taxes:</font></font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial">The Corporation&#8217;s effective income tax rate differs from the combined
Canadian federal and provincial statutory income tax rate for manufacturing and
processing companies.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial">The principal factors causing the difference are as follows:</font></div>

            </td>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="89%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">U.S. research and development and investment tax credits</font></td>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="1%">
            </td>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="1%">
            </td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="3%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">783</font></td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="1%">
            </td>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="1%">
            </td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="3%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">2,162</font></td>
          </tr><tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="left" nowrap width="1%">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</td>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="89%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">U.S. capital
      losses</font></td>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="1%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">
            </td>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="1%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">
            </td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="3%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; 180,761</font></td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="1%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">
            </td>
            <td align="left" nowrap width="1%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid">
            </td>
            <td align="right" nowrap width="3%" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1.5pt solid"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
171,338</font></td>
          </tr></table>
    </div><br>
    <div style="PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">The Canadian scientific research
expenditures may be carried forward indefinitely. The German losses from
operations may be used to offset future taxable income in Germany for corporate
tax and trade tax purposes and may be carried forward indefinitely. The U.S.
federal losses from operations may be used to offset future U.S. taxable income
and expire over the period from 2010 to 2029.</font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <div align="center"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">33 </font></div>
    <div>&#160;</div>
    <hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
    <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">
    </div><br>
    <div>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; ">
<tr valign="bottom">
            <td align="justify" nowrap width="100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">BALLARD POWER SYSTEMS
      INC.</font></font></td>

            <td align="justify" nowrap width="100%"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Notes to Consolidated Financial

            <td align="justify" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">Years ended December 31, 2009 and

            <td align="justify" nowrap width="100%"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: sans-serif">(Tabular amounts expressed in
